title: Single cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq)

source.description:
Remove biopsy frozen in
CryoStor solution in a
cryovial out of the liquid nitrogen tank
. Thaw frozen biopsy in a
water bath under constant swirling for 60-90 sec only until biopsy at the bottom is ice-free.

Transfer biopsy to plastic petri dish (ø 3.5 cm) filled with 1 ml DMEM/F12/10%FBS for
to wash off remaining DMSO at room temperature.

Transfer to second plastic petri dish (ø 3.5 cm) filled with 1 ml DMEM/F12/10%FBS and incubate for
at room temperature.
Take picture of biopsy together with a ruler.
Cut biopsy in ~1 mm long pieces using a scalpel.

Prepare dissociation medium:
DMEM/F12 (no FBS) and
µl Liberase TL (conc.: 2.5 mg/ml H2O, final enzyme conc.: 0.25 mg/ml in
Eppendorf tube (noBind).

Transfer biopsy tissue to prepared dissociation medium prewarmed to
.

Incubate at
for
and shake at 500 rpm in an
Eppendorf Thermomixer.

Triturate after
for 15 times with wide bore
pipette tip.

Stop reaction with
DMEM/F12/10%FBS (room temperature) and gently mix.

Incubate for
at room temperature.

Filter through
30 µm gaze (Miltenyi) into
tube on ice.

Push tissue through gaze using a
syringe plunger (rubber side).

Wash filter with
cold DMEM/F12/10%FBS.

Filter single cell suspension again through new 30 µm gaze (Miltenyi) into a second
tube.

Wash first
tube with
cold DMEM/F12/10% FBS and apply through 30 µm gaze into second
tube.

Centrifuge cell suspension at 200 x g for
at
.

Remove supernatant using glass Pasteur pipette and house vacuum. (~
remain)

Add and dispense cell pellet carefully with
DMEM/F12/10%FBS.

Take
for cell count and mix with
Trypan blue.
Count viable cells on hemocytometer or with automated cell counter (Countess)
Submit to 10X Genomics Chromium platform.

Load up to 10,000 viable cells in up to
of the cell suspension to 10X Chromium array ASAP.

Place the
cryovial with
HypoThermosol on ice
Add the renal biopsy specimen to the cryovial with HypoThermosol immediately.

Keep upright and at
(on ice) between the collection step and the cryopreservation step.

Place the
cryovial with
CryoStor on ice.
Transfer the renal biopsy specimen to the cryovial with CryoStor CS10 very quickly.

Keep the cryovial upright and on ice for
to allow permeabilization.
Place the cryovial in a Mr. Frosty freezing unit containing isopropanol.

Place the Mr. Frosty container in the
freezer for
.
Transfer the cryovial from the Mr. Frosty container to liquid N2, submerged. (Cryovials can be shipped on dry ice)

Place the
cryovial with

Add the renal biopsy specimen to the cryovial with HypoThermosol immediately.

Keep upright and at
(on ice) between the collection step and the cryopreservation step.

Place the

Transfer the renal biopsy specimen to the cryovial with CryoStor CS10 very quickly.

Keep the cryovial upright and on ice for
to allow permeabilization.
Place the cryovial in a Mr. Frosty freezing unit containing isopropanol.

Place the Mr. Frosty container in the -80°C freezer for
.
Transfer the cryovial from the Mr. Frosty container to liquid N2, submerged. (Cryovials can be shipped on dry ice)

A fully dissociated, single-cell suspension is essential for the analysis of single-cell transcriptomes. a) Suspension cell lines, bead-enriched and flow-sorted cells can be used directly after washing. b) Adherent cell lines require trypsin treatment first. c) Single-cell suspension from tissues requires optimization of dissociation.

It is important to treat cells gently to minimize cell lysis and loss: a) When cells lyse, the mRNA will contaminate other GEMs. b) Wash and resuspend in PBS + 0.04% non-acetylated BSA to minimize cell loss during handling. c) Wash cells 2x using a wide-bore pipette tip to remove ambient RNA and contaminants.

Use a cell strainer to remove clumps or debris from washed cells. a) Cell debris and fibers can be counted as either dead or live cells, causing inaccurate counts. b) Cell debris and large clumps may clog or wet the chip.

Quantitate cells accurately before loading the system. a) Approximately 65% loaded cells will be recovered. b) Recommended range: 500 to 10,000 recovered cells. c) Under- or over-loading may impact application performance.

Store cells suspension on ice until you are ready to load the chip. a) Prepare cell suspension right before you are going to use it. b) Load cells as soon as possible after preparation, ideally within 30 min

Transfer cells in media to a
Eppendorf tube
Spin down cells to form pellet • Depending on cell size and concentration, pellet size varies
Remove supernatant
Gently add 1x PBS + 0.04% BSA away from cell pellet
Gently pipette mix with Wide Bore pipette tip
Repeat the wash one more time
Spin down cells to form pellet
Remove supernatant
Resuspend cells in 1x PBS + 0.04% BSA with gentle pipette mix • For accurate cell counting, do not invert tubes
Adjust to desired cell concentration as indicated in section 3.

Equilibrate Single Cell 3’ Gel Beads to room temperature for at least
, thaw reagents

Resuspend the RT primer in
l low TE buffer and prepare the thermal cycler.
Prepare Master Mix on ice. Do NOT add cells yet.
Place the Chip in the Holder before loading reagents
Handle the chip by its edges, taking care to avoid contacting the bottom surface (this helps to mitigate frictional charging)
Align the beveled corners at upper left and insert chip under the guide at the left edge of the recess in the holder
Press down on the right side of the chip until the spring loaded clip engages
Close the Holder and lay flat on benchtop

Dispense the
of Master Mix into each well of an 8-tube strip on a chilled metal block resting on ice. Then add the calculated volume of water into each strip tube.

The next step is critical to recovering the maximum number of cells. It is important to ensure that: a) all of the cells in the sample are suspended b) the sample is homogenous when adding the cell suspension volume to the Master Mix.
Estimate the volume of the cell suspension and set the pipette at half that volume for pipette mixing. Wide bore pipette tips are not necessary for this step
Pipette the required volume of cell suspension from the center of the suspension volume.
Add the appropriate volume (µl) of single cell suspension to each well of the tube strip containing the Master Mix.

With a pipette set to
gently pipette mix the combined cells and Master Mix 5 times while keeping the tube strip on a chilled metal block resting on ice.

Without discarding the pipette tips, transfer
Master Mix containing cells to the wells in the row labeled 1, taking care not to introduce bubbles.
After loading Master Mix, wait for
This wait time is required for correct priming of channels inside the Single Cell 3’ Chip
Then, immediately proceed to loading the Gel Beads

Snap the Single Cell 3’ Gel Bead Strip into a 10x Vortex Adapter and vortex for
. a) A 30 sec wait while vortexing the Single Cell 3’ Gel Bead Strip is required to ensure proper priming of the Master Mix containing cells in the Single Cell 3’ Chip.

Remove the Single Cell 3’ Gel Bead Strip and flick in a sharp, downward motion to ensure maximum recovery. Confirm that there are no bubbles at the bottom of the tube and that liquid levels are uniform.

source.description:
Transfer Partitioning Oil to a reservoir and load row labeled 3 a) Once oil is added, run the chip within
. The less time the chip sits, the better. b) NEVER forget to add full volume of oil – doing so can damage the Chromium™ Controller! c) Don’t leave oil in reagent reservoir for too long – avoid evaporation and contamination by particulates

source.title: Loading Gel Beads and Partitioning Oil

source.description: Attach the 10x™ Gasket. The notched cut should be at the top left corner. a) Ensure the gasket holes are aligned with the chip wells. b) Do not touch or “smooth” the top surface of the gasket. c) Keep the assembly horizontal to avoid wetting the 10x Gasket with Partitioning Oil.

source.description:
Transfer
GEMs to twinc.tec® PCR plate a) Aspirate GEMs • Within
of completed run • Pipette tip just above lowest point in recovery well • Do not take more than 100 µl or double-dip b) Dispense into PCR Plate • Pipette tip against side of well • Dispense slowly (20 sec) to avoid air bubbles • Keep plate on chilled block

source.title: Running the Chromium™ Controller and transferring GEMs from the Chip

source.description: Withdraw pipette tips from the wells and verify that there is no air in the tips. GEMs should appear opaque and uniform across all channels.
Seal plate with Bio-Rad PX1TM Plate Sealer a) Red stripe facing up b) A tight seal is critical to GEM stability
Cycle in Bio-Rad C1000 TouchTM thermal cycler with Deep Well Module

Store in the PCR plate at
for up to
before proceeding to Post GEM-RT Cleanup.

Add
of Recovery Agent directly to samples in PCR plate.

Wait
.

With the same tips, move entire volume to 8 tube strips. (If PCR strip tubes have been used for GEM-RT reaction, no volume transfer into a new 8 tube strip is necessary) a) Make sure to extract everything from the 96 well plate b) Do not vortex or pipette mix after adding Recovery Agent

Slowly remove
Recovery Agent/Partitioning Oil (pink) from the bottom of the tubes and discard a) Some Recovery Agent may remain b) Be careful to not aspirate any aqueous phase
Set up cDNA Amplification Master Mix a) The optimal number of cycles for the cDNA amplification reaction is a trade-off between generating sufficient mass and minimizing PCR amplification artifacts
SPRI Cleanup
Bioanalyzer QC. Optimal performance has been characterized on input cDNA with a mean length > 2 kb.

The library mRNA prep is sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform. The output from the sequencer is then analyzed using the 10XGenomics software CellRanger. This step includes the alignment of the reads to human genome (GRCH38). The raw file output from CellRanger is further processed using Seurat R package. The downstream processing includes: Log transformation, filtering out cells with < 500 genes (or < 400 UMI) and > 5000 genes, filtering out cells with mitochondrial content > 20%, scaling based on UMI count, mitochondrial read content, principal component analysis, unsupervised clustering based on significant pca components, tSNEplot visualization and differential expression analysis using Wilcox test. The library mRNA prep is sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform. The output from the sequencer is then analyzed using the 10XGenomics software CellRanger. This step includes the alignment of the reads to human genome (GRCH38). The raw file output from CellRanger is further processed using Seurat R package. The downstream processing includes: Log transformation, filtering out cells with < 500 genes (or < 400 UMI) and > 5000 genes, filtering out cells with mitochondrial content > 20%, scaling based on UMI count, mitochondrial read content, principal component analysis, unsupervised clustering based on significant pca components, tSNEplot visualization and differential expression analysis using Wilcox test.

materials.name: Cryovial, PP, 1.8ml, external cap, 13mmx46mm, sterile,with Silicone washer
Nunc™ IVF Petri Dishes, Untreated; 35 x 10mm petri dish

description: Previously, RNA sequencing for whole-genome gene expression analysis could only be performed on whole tissue (bulk RNA seq), or microdissected tissue compartments, where gene expression measurements reflect an average across all captured cell types. Single cell RNA sequencing allows the measurement and comparison of gene expression of individual cells and thus capture the previously underappreciated cellular heterogeneity within tissues such as the kidney. Our protocol allows the dissociation of a single kidney biopsy core to a single cell suspension. The total mRNA from each living cell is then captured, uniquely barcoded, and gene expression profiled with RNAseq. Single cell transcriptomics of adult kidney tissue is performed using 10X Genomics droplet-based technology. 10X Genomics technology combines microfluidics with molecular barcoding and custom bioinformatics software (CellRanger). High-throughput single cell transcriptomic measurements enable profiling of individual cell types.
